abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory,
            sustainability is highly likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. However, and in contrast
            to the satisfactory performance of the Borrower, the Bank
            performance is unsatisfactory, on the grounds that project
            design, with too many unrelated sub-components, led to
            unsustainable supervision costs, and, the process to
            restructure the project, and cancel credit lines, should
            have been taken much earlier. Lessons suggest that project
            design, and preparation be simple, to avoid multiple
            objectives requiring substantial supervision resources, and,
            long implementation periods impose high costs in terms of
            Government oversight, potentially reducing flexibility.
            Credit lines design should consider a banking environment
            with no distortions, or at least only few distortions, in
            the credit markets. Interest rate ceilings existed in Cyprus
            at the time the Bank extended the credit line, and it
            negatively affected credit demand. Furthermore, under
            intense restructuring of the enterprise sector, private
            financing needs become difficult to assess, thus it would be
            preferable to initiate smaller credit lines to be tested,
            and perfected in time, to form a solid base in assessing the
            real demand. Technical assistance should be clearly defined,
            not financed by the Bank if grant funds are available, and,
            should be responsive to client needs.
